[This is the sixth of the series of
articles on war problems written for'

The war has brought into
higher prominence than ever the
rights, privileges and misfortunes
of the small nation. The territories, the political institutions, the
lives of the inhabitants have been
ruthlessly trodden under foot. In
fact, this disregard of common humanity, not to speak of solemn
treaty obligations, is the thing
which has drawn the civilized nations of the world, one by one,
into this conflict. As we look forward to the expected victory over
the marauding powers the questions of settlement loom into
larger and larger view. Foremost
among these are the measures to
be taken to prevent such outbreaks in the future. "The world
must be made safe for democracy," to be sure, but the system
by which this security is to be
maintained is not so easy either
to define or to adopt.
Some method will be-found, but
in the process further questions
must be answered as to what constitutes a nation. The philosophers, the philologians and the
practical politicians have all confidently supplied their replies, but
neither the pedagogue nor the
demagogue can determine alone
the practical, political and ethnological puzzle which the map of
Europe now presents. Consequently, I do not propose to solve
the problem here. It is wise, however, to consider the intricacy of
the subject in advance, so that
when the peace negotiators get together we may judge whether we,
as well as the nations involved,
are to get the results for which
we fought.
The nineteenth century has witnessed a great revival of national
spirit based on remembrance of
former conditions and vitalized by
common language and literature.
One can only sympathize with
these cultural aspirations, but it
is quite another question to decide whether political boundaries
should be made to conform to the
limits of language or dialect.

The simplest problem appears to
be the demand of Italy that she be
given the borderlands occupied by
an Italian-speaking population.
In the Trentino this nearly corresponds to suitable geographical
boundaries and a compromise
ought to be found without too
much difficulty. Indeed, we are
told that Austria, in order to prevent Italy from going into the
war, offered to cede the province
of Trent up to the actual Sprachgrenze.
Italy, however, wished to go
further, so that the iatlusion of
another valley would strengthen
her defensive position. Thus language and political geography conflict, though doubtless a compromise can be reached. Italian Dalmatia is now become Slavic and a
whole Italian state in Switzerland
has no desire to be joined to Italy.
So language fails as a criterion.
It seems imperative that Belgium should be restored to its peo.
pie, but if nationality should rest
on language we are confronted by
the fact that Flemish is spoken
by a large portion of the people
and for the rest their speech is
French. Some other principle
must be found to settle this case.
In the Balkan peninsula and on
the eastern front the linguistic
situation is far more complicated.
The Balkan wars of many genera-

tions have been waged by peoples
related in language, but who differed slightly in religious belief.
The focus of this conflict is found
in Macedonia, where the races and
religions overlap. This has been
for ages a heated inciting pot in
which the Serbs, Bulgarians,
Greeks, Albanians and Turks have
displayed their refractory qualities.
The mark of distinction here is
religion. The Serbs hold to the
original Greek Church, while the
Bulgarians have for some time
maintained a Greek ritual with a
patriarch of their own. The two
peoples are racially related, but
in the disputed territory they
have been persecuting one another to the limit of endurance.
The Serbs have now been driven
from their country by the Central
Powers and should have it restored, but the world can no
longer look with patience on this
murderous quarrel between the
small states. Some means must
be found to keep the peace, based on
considerations other than linguistic or religious.
A political arrangement that
will permit the cultural and economic development of each of
these peoples must be the task of
the coming peace congress. It will
not be easy. The Greek is dreaming of ancient Byzantium when
Constantinople was the center of
Greek civilization. Not only that,
but his fellow countrymen now
hold the fringes of the Aegean
Sea in the grip of their commercial enterprises. The Bulgarian
wants a coast line on the Black
Sea and the Mediterranean at the
same time. The Serb wants an
outlet to the Adriatic. All of
these demands are such that the
lines of demarkation could not follow language boundaries exclusively.
If Rumania were to include all
of the people who speak a common
tongue, it would absorb a large
piece of Hungary and a part of
the Russian province of Bessarabia. The latter was wrongfully, taken away in peace negotiations in 1878, when Russia had the
power to dominate small nations,
but for Rumania to annex Hungarian Transylvania opens a question in which political consequences as well as racial affinity
must be considered. The Hungarian government of its Rumanian subjects has been selfish and
cruel. The attempt to make them
into Magyars by suppressing the
Rumanian elementary schools and
by forbidding the language in
church services has the familiar
Bismarckian ring.
On the map the Rumanianspeaking population lies compactly in a large circle, cutting into
Hungary and Russia. It is divided by mountain chains and
large rivers, but it would seem
that so long as Hungary maintains its repressive attitude separation is tlie only hope for the cultural aspirations of this people.

The Poles have never forgotten
that they once were independent.
They were not very successful in
self-government, and it was in
part their own fault that they
were absorbed by the surrounding states. As a whole, however,
it was forcible dismemberment by
powerful nations whom they could
not have resisted. Their treatment by Russia and Prussia has
been a further wanton disregard
of their national self-respect and
their natural rights. Yet the restoration at this late hour will be
no easy task when it comes to fixing the boundaries of a Polish
state. How much shall the outlying fringes of Prussia and Austria be cut off to make a satisfactory Poland? Shall a strip be
cut tWoug the heart of Prussia
to give the Poles their ancient
city of Danzig and access to the
sea? Germany will need to be
badly beaten to gain her consent
to this.
From these few examples it
would appear that no single rigid
definition of nationality will be
satisfactory in actual practice. In
fixing the limits of nations some
regard must be paid to accomplished facts in history, to economic conditions and in part to
strategic considerations. At the
same time the wishes of the people in a given geographic group
ought to be regarded, when that
group desires and is conscious of
political adhesion, whether they
speak one language or three.
The rise of nationalism has been
due to the artificial repression of
cultural aspirations of language
groups. In Austria the German
general government prohibited for
years the teaching of Czechish to
the Bohemians. In Prussia the
Polish population has been given
the third degree of Germanization.
Russia went as far as it could in
the same direction in its part of
Poland. The small nations have
seen no remedy except complete
political independence.
The peace conferences at the
end of this world war cannot overlook the call of these _national and
cultural groups, yet certain economic considerations must not be
neglected. The small nation is
not necessarily a good business
proposition, either to itself or to
the world at large. If we are to
see tariff barriers set up at every
new boundary, and currency systems changing every few hours on
a railway journey, the economic
conditions of Europe will be set
back two centuries. The modern
world is too interdependent to be
satisfied with this, consequently
the articles of peace will only
postpone the war if they do not
provide for international comity
in trade relations.
In some cases a political separation may not be necessary. It
may well be the duty of a world
congress to exact guarantees from
larger powers that the national
groups within their boundaries

Remember the Tuscania!

In the last week we felt the
shock of the first blow from our
enemy across the sea; that blow,
regardless of the despicable, unAerhand manner in which it was
dealt, was measured in the lives
of more than two hundred of
our boys. Lest we forget, we
are engaged with Germany in
a fight for our lives, for our
country and the ideals it represents. Every blow counts for
what it is—measured in blood and
treasure, not in chivalry and heroism. Germany has landed the first
telling blow of the conflict we
know it because we felt it. What
shall be our answer to the sinking
of the Tuscania?
If we may judge by precedent,
that answer will be "Remember the
Tuscania!" translated into action
in terms of an unfailing determination to crush that intolerable
Prussian military machine and
the unfaltering support—tothelast
iota of our resources and strength
—of time American Army in
France. It is almost exactly a
score of years since, that the loss
of approximately the same number of lives by the same insidious,
cowardly methods brought this
nation to its feet and to its arms
with the cry from a hundred million throats: "Remember the
Maine!" The same deepfelt indignation and angry determination
that shook the nation in '98 has
shaken it today. As was the coun-

try momentarily mobilized tw.enty
years ago, so will it be today.
In times like these, we who are
still at college feel helpless and
useless and hopeless; in our position-3,000 miles away from the
enemy's front line—we can't, at
least for a while, return blow
for blow; we can only talk and •
drill and study, and believe men
like Sir Walter when they tell us
that we should finish our college
work. But Sir Walter told us that
we could and must do more than
that. It isfor us to back our soldiers
in France and our sailorson the sea
to our last ounce of strength and
our last atom of resources. If you
will read the special editorial elsewhere on this page, you will understand that wars must be
fought with money as well as with
men; that we must practice thrift
if we are to win the war. The success of Government loans and
bond issues means not one wit less
than a great military victory;
and, moreover, the importance of •
the issues may not be measured
by the denominations into which
they are divided, but only by their
complete success. Over two hundred Americans went bravely
down to a watery grave for the
sake of every one of us. Over a
million pore are courageously
facing death among the hills of
France. In order that those boys

(A special editorial, written for THE NEWSLETTER by an international authority on public
finance.)

There have been since the entrance of this country into the
great war a number of campaigns
for funds either for government
loans or for such activities as the
Red Cross or the Y. M. C. A.
These campaigns were, of course,
absolutely necessary. For money
had to be secured for the conduct
of the war. Without it effective
action was impossible.
There is a danger that the emphasis which has been laid on
subscriptions of money may lead
the average person to conclude
that his duty is performed when
he makes his subscription. But
while money is a necessity, money
will not win the war. Even an
inexhaustible supply of. gold or
credits is of use only in so far as
it facilitates the manufacture of
the things needed for military operations. Gold of itself will not
secure a supply of ships, of airplanes, of cannon, of rifles, of
munitions and of the thousand
and one timings which a modern
army must have.
The timings which an army needs
must be made. They'do not exist
and therefore cannot be bought.
In order that they may be made,
panes must be worked, railways
must operate, factories must produce and men and women must
labor.
In alinost every country in time
of peace most of time labor avail- •
able is employed for the production of the things demanded in a
time of peace. When war conies
some of that labor must be diverted from the things demanded
in time of peace to the things
needed in time of war. "Besiness as usual" is a slogan which
is as foolish as it is futile, and
spells defeat in the great enterprise into which a nation in war
times has entered.
The industry of time country
must in these war times submit
to great modification. The factory which has produced motor
cars must devote itself to airplanes and motor trucks. The
shop which made clothes must
make uniforms. In order that
this modification of industry may
be made the buyer of a motor car
must put off his purchase. The
man who is accustomed to have
a new suit at certain seasons

must ask himself whether his old
suit will not last another year.
No matter what a man's means
may be, he should in 'such times
as these in which we are now living consider before making any
purchase, not so much whether
he can personally afford to buy,
but rather whether he really is
in need and whether, in case he
denies himself, Ile will not be contributing even in a small way towards freeing labor which may
be used to produce the things the
army needs.
If we all can acqpire this attitude of mind we shall furthermore be aiding in accomplishing
another result which can be
reached only in this way. We
shall be saving money which,
through taxes and loans, we can
give the Government to pay for
the new products which military
necessities require. The war must
be financed out of income. If I
sell a house or dispose of any part
of my capital in order to pay the
taxes which the Government demands of me or in order to subscribe to a Government loan to
the extent that I increase my own
ability to give may money.to the
Government, I am diminishing the
ability of some one else. It is
true he might be unwilling to do
what I am doing; so far as that
is the case I am helping the Government. But I am by selling
my property in no way increasing the resources of the country.
I shall, however, be of great
help to the .Government if I economize in my expenditures and give
what I save. I may not be able to
save quickly enough to meet the
Government's immediate needs.
In that case I may by borrowing
from a bank anticipate my savings. But whether I contribute
my present or my future savings
I shall be giving of my income
and what I give will increase the
amount available for the use of
the Government not offset in any
way by the diminution of the ability of some one else.
It is said that he gives twice
who gives quickly. In these times
it may also be said that he who
saves accomplishes a double purpose. On the one hand he discourages the making of things
which are for the moment un-,
necessary. On the other, he furthers the production of what is
needed, and at the same time increases the means—in the only
way in which they can be increased—for the purchase of the
timings innnediately needful.
Economy by the rich and devotion of their savings to the purchase of Government loans will
not be sufficient. If, we are to
free the labor necessary for the
production of the timings needed
in time war, and if we are to secure the funds wherewith to pay
for.these things, the great mass of
people must economize. It is in
order to enable those not of large
means to save that the War Savings Stamps have been provided.

The war has brought into
higher prominence than ever the
rights, privileges and misfortunes
of the small nation. The territories, the political institutions, the
lives of the inhabitants have been
ruthlessly trodden under foot. In
fact, this disregard of common humanity, not to speak of solemn
treaty obligations, is the thing
which has drawn the civilized nations of the world, one by one,
into this conflict. As we look forward to the expected victory over
the marauding powers the questions of settlement loom into
larger and larger view. Foremost
among these are the measures to
be taken to prevent such outbreaks in the future. "The world
must be made safe for democracy," to be sure, but the system
by which this security is to be
maintained is not so easy either
to define or to adopt.
Some method will be-found, but
in the process further questions
must be answered as to what constitutes a nation. The philosophers, the philologians and the
practical politicians have all confidently supplied their replies, but
neither the pedagogue nor the
demagogue can determine alone
the practical, political and ethnological puzzle which the map of
Europe now presents. Consequently, I do not propose to solve
the problem here. It is wise, however, to consider the intricacy of
the subject in advance, so that
when the peace negotiators get together we may judge whether we,
as well as the nations involved,
are to get the results for which
we fought.
The nineteenth century has witnessed a great revival of national
spirit based on remembrance of
former conditions and vitalized by
common language and literature.
One can only sympathize with
these cultural aspirations, but it
is quite another question to decide whether political boundaries
should be made to conform to the
limits of language or dialect.

The simplest problem appears to
be the demand of Italy that she be
given the borderlands occupied by
an Italian-speaking population.
In the Trentino this nearly corresponds to suitable geographical
boundaries and a compromise
ought to be found without too
much difficulty. Indeed, we are
told that Austria, in order to prevent Italy from going into the
war, offered to cede the province
of Trent up to the actual Sprachgrenze.
Italy, however, wished to go
further, so that the iatlusion of
another valley would strengthen
her defensive position. Thus language and political geography conflict, though doubtless a compromise can be reached. Italian Dalmatia is now become Slavic and a
whole Italian state in Switzerland
has no desire to be joined to Italy.
So language fails as a criterion.
It seems imperative that Belgium should be restored to its peo.
pie, but if nationality should rest
on language we are confronted by
the fact that Flemish is spoken
by a large portion of the people
and for the rest their speech is
French. Some other principle
must be found to settle this case.
In the Balkan peninsula and on
the eastern front the linguistic
situation is far more complicated.
The Balkan wars of many genera-

tions have been waged by peoples
related in language, but who differed slightly in religious belief.
The focus of this conflict is found
in Macedonia, where the races and
religions overlap. This has been
for ages a heated inciting pot in
which the Serbs, Bulgarians,
Greeks, Albanians and Turks have
displayed their refractory qualities.
The mark of distinction here is
religion. The Serbs hold to the
original Greek Church, while the
Bulgarians have for some time
maintained a Greek ritual with a
patriarch of their own. The two
peoples are racially related, but
in the disputed territory they
have been persecuting one another to the limit of endurance.
The Serbs have now been driven
from their country by the Central
Powers and should have it restored, but the world can no
longer look with patience on this
murderous quarrel between the
small states. Some means must
be found to keep the peace, based on
considerations other than linguistic or religious.
A political arrangement that
will permit the cultural and economic development of each of
these peoples must be the task of
the coming peace congress. It will
not be easy. The Greek is dreaming of ancient Byzantium when
Constantinople was the center of
Greek civilization. Not only that,
but his fellow countrymen now
hold the fringes of the Aegean
Sea in the grip of their commercial enterprises. The Bulgarian
wants a coast line on the Black
Sea and the Mediterranean at the
same time. The Serb wants an
outlet to the Adriatic. All of
these demands are such that the
lines of demarkation could not follow language boundaries exclusively.
If Rumania were to include all
of the people who speak a common
tongue, it would absorb a large
piece of Hungary and a part of
the Russian province of Bessarabia. The latter was wrongfully, taken away in peace negotiations in 1878, when Russia had the
power to dominate small nations,
but for Rumania to annex Hungarian Transylvania opens a question in which political consequences as well as racial affinity
must be considered. The Hungarian government of its Rumanian subjects has been selfish and
cruel. The attempt to make them
into Magyars by suppressing the
Rumanian elementary schools and
by forbidding the language in
church services has the familiar
Bismarckian ring.
On the map the Rumanianspeaking population lies compactly in a large circle, cutting into
Hungary and Russia. It is divided by mountain chains and
large rivers, but it would seem
that so long as Hungary maintains its repressive attitude separation is tlie only hope for the cultural aspirations of this people.

that they once were independent.
They were not very successful in

it was forcible dismemberment by
powerful nations whom they could

been a further wanton disregard
of their national self-respect and
their natural rights. Yet the restoration at this late hour will be
no easy task when it comes to fixing the boundaries of a Polish
state. How much shall the outlying fringes of Prussia and Austria be cut off to make a satisfactory Poland? Shall a strip be

From these few examples it

definition of nationality will be
satisfactory in actual practice. In

strategic considerations. At the
same time the wishes of the people in a given geographic group

group desires and is conscious of
political adhesion, whether they
speak one language or three.
The rise of nationalism has been

cultural aspirations of language

shock of the first blow from our
enemy across the sea; that blow,
regardless of the despicable, unAerhand manner in which it was

our boys. Lest we forget, we
are engaged with Germany in

country and the ideals it represents. Every blow counts for

telling blow of the conflict we
know it because we felt it. What
shall be our answer to the sinking
of the Tuscania?
If we may judge by precedent,
that answer will be "Remember the
Tuscania!" translated into action

Prussian military machine and
the unfaltering support—tothelast

nation to its feet and to its arms

down to a watery grave for the
sake of every one of us. Over a

he makes his subscription. But
while money is a necessity, money
will not win the war. Even an
inexhaustible supply of. gold or
credits is of use only in so far as
it facilitates the manufacture of
the things needed for military operations. Gold of itself will not
secure a supply of ships, of airplanes, of cannon, of rifles, of
munitions and of the thousand
and one timings which a modern
army must have.
The timings which an army needs
must be made. They'do not exist
and therefore cannot be bought.
In order that they may be made,
panes must be worked, railways
must operate, factories must produce and men and women must
labor.
In alinost every country in time
of peace most of time labor avail- •
able is employed for the production of the things demanded in a
time of peace. When war conies
some of that labor must be diverted from the things demanded
in time of peace to the things
needed in time of war. "Besiness as usual" is a slogan which
is as foolish as it is futile, and
spells defeat in the great enterprise into which a nation in war
times has entered.
The industry of time country
must in these war times submit
to great modification. The factory which has produced motor
cars must devote itself to airplanes and motor trucks. The
shop which made clothes must
make uniforms. In order that
this modification of industry may
be made the buyer of a motor car
must put off his purchase. The
man who is accustomed to have
a new suit at certain seasons

must ask himself whether his old
suit will not last another year.
No matter what a man's means
may be, he should in 'such times
as these in which we are now living consider before making any
purchase, not so much whether
he can personally afford to buy,
but rather whether he really is
in need and whether, in case he
denies himself, Ile will not be contributing even in a small way towards freeing labor which may
be used to produce the things the
army needs.
If we all can acqpire this attitude of mind we shall furthermore be aiding in accomplishing
another result which can be
reached only in this way. We
shall be saving money which,
through taxes and loans, we can
give the Government to pay for
the new products which military
necessities require. The war must
be financed out of income. If I
sell a house or dispose of any part
of my capital in order to pay the
taxes which the Government demands of me or in order to subscribe to a Government loan to
the extent that I increase my own
ability to give may money.to the
Government, I am diminishing the
ability of some one else. It is
true he might be unwilling to do
what I am doing; so far as that
is the case I am helping the Government. But I am by selling
my property in no way increasing the resources of the country.
I shall, however, be of great
help to the .Government if I economize in my expenditures and give
what I save. I may not be able to
save quickly enough to meet the
Government's immediate needs.
In that case I may by borrowing
from a bank anticipate my savings. But whether I contribute
my present or my future savings
I shall be giving of my income
and what I give will increase the
amount available for the use of
the Government not offset in any
way by the diminution of the ability of some one else.
It is said that he gives twice
who gives quickly. In these times
it may also be said that he who
saves accomplishes a double purpose. On the one hand he discourages the making of things
which are for the moment un-,
necessary. On the other, he furthers the production of what is
needed, and at the same time increases the means—in the only
way in which they can be increased—for the purchase of the
timings innnediately needful.

not be sufficient. If, we are to
free the labor necessary for the
production of the timings needed
in time war, and if we are to secure the funds wherewith to pay

people must economize. It is in

means to save that the War Savings Stamps have been provided.
